definition: mutually shirking responsibilities (idiom); each blaming the other/passing the buck to and fro/each trying to unload responsibilities onto the other
mutual
each other/one another/mutually/fret on the neck of a pipa 琵琶[pi2 pa5] (a fret on the soundboard is called a 品[pin3])
surname Xiang
appearance/portrait/picture/government minister/(physics) phase/(literary) to appraise (esp. by scrutinizing physical features)/to read sb's fortune (by physiognomy, palmistry etc)
to push/to cut/to refuse/to reject/to decline/to shirk (responsibility)/to put off/to delay/to push forward/to nominate/to elect/massage
to shirk/to give excuses

sentences.english: If both sides is mutual buck-passing, how can you do again?
sentences.chinese: 假如双方互相推诿责任，你又能怎么办？

definition: to pass the buck/to shirk responsibility
to kick a ball around/(fig.) to mutually shirk responsibility/to pass the buck
to decline/to avoid/shirking responsibilities/to blame others/to pass the buck/to unload one's responsibilities/to try to get out of a task
to wrangle/wrangling
to skimp on the job/to work half-heartedly/not to take the job seriously
variant of 推諉|推诿[tui1 wei3]
more hands than needed (idiom); too many cooks spoil the broth
to do things each in one's own way
each one does what he thinks is right (idiom)/each goes his own way
each sticks to his own view (idiom); a dialogue of the deaf
to try to smooth things over/to paper over the issues/to gloss things over
to put the blame on sb else
to neglect one's duty/dereliction of duty/malpractice
breach of responsibility/failure to carry out one's duty
each sticks to his own opinion (idiom); chacun son gout
